Key Arguments: The definitions of misinformation and disinformation in the draft Bill are unclear and prolix.
The legislation detracts from existing protections under Australian Consumer Law by excluding certain modes of communication.
Mainstream media, educational institutions, and government information are excluded, targeting alternative news sources.
The criteria for 'serious harm' are vague and subjective, potentially leading to arbitrary censorship.
The legislation overlooks harms based on sex, focusing instead on other protected attributes.
The proposed legislation could lead to censorship motivated by commercial or ideological considerations.
Main Themes: Concerns about censorship and freedom of expression
Criticism of vague and unclear legislative definitions
Perceived political motivation and bias in targeting alternative media
Exclusion of sex as a protected attribute
Notable Quotes: Who will be the arbiters of truth?
This legislation ensures government and corporations with control of major media outlets are not only free to mislead and deceive but are also empowered to effectively shut down all dissent.
Please do not take this next step towards an Orwellian dystopia.
